item.name: 1812: The Invasion of Canada
item.wishlistcomment: Simple rules, fairly quick, and 2-5 players... seems like the perfect game to introduce Katie and our weekly board game group to wargames!

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment:
A favorite of mine that gets play with Katie, family, and our board game group. Lots of interesting strategical play with 2-4 players, and a great quick-playing light game with 5-7 players.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]4/5[/i] [b]#2[/b] [i]in Katie's Top Ten[/i] [b]#10[/b] [i]in Matt's Top Fifty[/i]

item.name: 7 Wonders: Leaders
item.wishlistcomment: One of our most played games, and now that most of our group is familiar with the original game, I'm looking forward to adding this to our collection for some more variety.

item.name: Acquire
item.comment:
An old favorite that I grew up playing, though I think Airlines Europe has surpassed it as far as games with stock and majority awards go.
3/5
item.wishlistcomment: Played a ton growing up, still one of my favorites. Would love to get my hands on one of the older versions that I grew up with, particularly the plastic one with buildings.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment:
Just played it for the first time and loved it. I was surprisingly easy to learn the basic mechanisms and how to play, though it seems that learning the underlying strategy and how to play well is quite complex and will take many plays to grasp.
[b]Initial Impression[/b] - [i]4/5[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: A favorite that someone else in our board game group has, would love to add it to our own collection along with The Goodies.

item.name: Airlines Europe
item.comment:
I love the combination of stock options with pseudo route-building for the various airlines. While it can be compared to Acquire and Ticket to Ride (and I prefer it over both of those), it doesn't play particularly like either one of them and has a unique style and feel to it that I have not yet found in anything else.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]4/5[/i]

item.name: Among the Stars
item.wishlistcomment: This one seems to be sorta like a science-fiction version of 7 Wonders? 7 Wonders is my wife's second favorite game and comes in at #8 on my top ten list, so this seems like a no-brainer to check out.

item.name: Android: Netrunner
item.comment:
I absolutely love this game. I love that you play the deck, rather than building a deck and having the deck play itself. The bluffing mechanisms and gameplay really shine. There are a multitude of choices on your turn, and you never feel like you lose this game because of a bad draw. You feel like the other player out-witted you, and things would have gone differently if you had played better.
It's been four months since release and we're above 80 plays (making it our most played game, ever) with no signs of slowing down. This is my favorite game of all-time, bar none.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]5/5[/i] [b]#1[/b] [i]in Matt's Top Ten[/i]

item.name: Android: Netrunner – A Study in Static
Archipelago
item.wishlistcomment: Updated 11/13/13 - A heavy worker-placement euro game with theme and interaction, sign me up! I also love the hidden victory conditions that change each game. The downside is even the short game appears to be very long, and it would never make it to the table on our regular weekly board game night.

item.name: Arkham Horror
item.comment:
Didn't make the greatest of first impressions with us, as we found it impossible to win. Turns out, the person teaching it to us was playing incorrectly (one mythos turn per player; not per round) and stacking the odds impossibly against us. I would love another opportunity to play it again, correctly. That said, Katie was rather overwhelmed by everything going on and the incredible difficulty pushed her over the edge. She doesn't plan on ever playing AH again, so we might have to successfully work through Elder Sign and Mansions of Madness to pick this one up again.
3/5
item.wishlistcomment: Played once and wasn't too sure what to think afterwards. I think we'd prefer Mansions of Madness.

item.name: Bananagrams
item.comment:
I just can't stand word games, and this takes a hit because of that.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]1/5[/i]

item.name: Battlestar Galactica
item.comment:
A ton of fun with the right group of folks, if overly long and tedious on occasion. We had a few bad experiences with Cylon sympathizers in play, will do my best to avoid future player counts with sympathizers.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i] [b]#37 [/b] in [i]Matt's Top Fifty[/i]

item.name: Betrayal at House on the Hill
item.comment:
Very simple gameplay and quite dull throughout the first half of the game in repeat playthroughs, but the second half of the game following the haunt more than makes up for it. Some of the haunts' rules are a bit quirky, however we thoroughly enjoyed all of them and it was quite a hit with our friends as well.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i] [b]Not Ranked[/b] in [i]Matt's Top Fifty[/i]

item.name: Boss Monster: The Dungeon Building Card Game
Ca$h 'n Gun$
item.wishlistcomment: Updated 11/13/13 - We are always looking for party games that are easy for non-gamers to pick up and allows several players to play at once. This is near the top of our list, but it unfortunately appears that it will stay here until a reprint or new version is released.

item.name: Castles of Mad King Ludwig
item.comment:
Remember Ted Alspach's Suburbia being near the top of my 2012 list? Well, he topped himself here in its spiritual successor. It captures the same building spirit of Suburbia, but focuses it on designing a castle instead of a city. Theme aside, the most noteworthy change is the removal of reputation and income (a very, very fiddly mechanism from Suburbia) with the addition of a master builder who sets the price and gets paid for the individual pieces of the castle. It's a very simple mechanism that adds much more interesting gameplay elements.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]4/5[/i] [b]#3[/b] [i]in Matt's Favorite Board Games of 2014[/i]

item.name: Clash of Cultures
item.wishlistcomment: Updated 11/13/13 - My interest is quite piqued, but I'm putting this on the back-burner until I get around to playing Sid Meier's Civ and Through the Ages... both of which we own but have gone unplayed.

item.name: Cyclades
item.wishlistcomment: Updated 11/13/13 - Katie absolutely loves games with auctions and I love games with area control and conflict, so this game might just appeal quite a bit to both of us. Also heavily considering Kemet, but I think the Greek mythos appeals more to Katie than Egyptian.

item.name: Doctor Who: The Card Game
item.wishlistcomment: I'm slowly becoming a Doctor Who fan, and I have a few friends who are HUGE fans. This would get to the table a lot based on theme alone.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment:
Another favorite of ours. As a newbie to "real" board gaming, I had no idea there were games out there not based entirely on dice rolls and luck. This game puts everyone at equal footing at the beginning of the game and allows each individual strategy to determine your fate. The practically innumerable variants in card choices keep on your toes and allow you to constantly discover and develop new strategies. It revolutionized board games in our lives and opened our eyes to what's out there, and it will always be a centerpiece in our growing collection.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]4/5[/i] [b]#4[/b] [i]in Katie's Top Ten[/i] [b]#9[/b] [i]in Matt's Top Ten[/i]

item.name: Eclipse
item.wishlistcomment: I have been contemplating a 4X game for a while, and our weekly game group loves science fiction themes AND eurogames, this seems like the next step up for our group... if we can ever find it for a decent price.

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple
Five Tribes
item.comment:
It turns out that Mancala with a variable board, area control, and set collection is pretty awesome. Don't be deceived by Days of Wonder publishing it, this is very much a connoisseur's game and not their usual gateway material.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]4/5[/i] [b]#2[/b] [i]in Matt's Favorite Board Games of 2014[/i]

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue
item.comment:
Very similar mechanisms to that of Pandemic, with a very different theme. This is probably going to come down to which theme you enjoy more, but I have to say I prefer Flash Point's theming and components. That said, it feels so similar to Pandemic (which we already own), that I doubt we'll ever purchase Flash Point.
4/5
item.wishlistcomment: Very similar mechanisms to that of Pandemic, with a very different theme. This is probably going to come down to which theme you enjoy more, but I have to say I prefer Flash Point's theming and components. That said, it feels so similar to Pandemic (which we already own), that I doubt we'll ever purchase Flash Point.

item.name: FlowerFall
item.comment:
Played for the first time the other day. It's quite innovative and unique when compared with the other games we've played. This may become one of my favorite light fillers.
[b]Initial Impression[/b] - [i]3/5[/i]

item.name: Fluxx
item.comment:
Katie enjoys this one quite a bit, but I really struggle attempting to have a fun time while playing this game. It plays akin to Uno, with rule changes, reading on the fly, and numerous occasions for AP-prone players to stall the game to a complete stop. For what should be a relatively simple card game, I have had far too many 1-1.5 hour games that seemed to drag on forever. If I'm going to dedicate that sort of time to a card game, I'd rather play through several games of Monopoly Deal or 3-4 matches of A Game of Thrones LCG. That much time spent on this card game is a waste, to me.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]1/5[/i]

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.wishlistcomment: I am a huge fan of Vlaada Chvatil (as are most of our weekly board game group's members) and this would be a great addition to our group's collection.

item.name: The Game of Life: Card Game
A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition)
item.comment:
A favorite of mine. The hidden simultaneous action placement mechanism guarantees tension throughout the game worthy of the series, just waiting for your allies to stab you in the back.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]4/5[/i] [b]#5[/b] [i]in Matt's Top Fifty[/i]

item.name: A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition) – A Feast for Crows
A Game of Thrones: The Card Game
item.comment:
My first LCG, and a favorite for a while. I still keep a competition-level deck ready for each House and I still thoroughly enjoy the game, but Netrunner has completely replaced my AGoT playing time and is much more accessible to other family and board game group members.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]5/5[/i] [b]#3[/b] [i]in Matt's Top Ten[/i]

item.name: Game of Thrones: The Card Game
A Game of Thrones: The Card Game (Second Edition)
Gauntlet of Fools
item.wishlistcomment: Typical take-that type of card game. Might be a worthy replacement for Munchkin in our collection.

item.name: Good Cop Bad Cop
item.comment:
My highest ranked social deduction game since Coup? I believe so. Has a Cash 'n' Guns vibe to it while maintaining the deduction aspects of Resistance or Coup.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i] [b]#8[/b] [i]in Matt's Favorite Board Games of 2014[/i]

item.name: Ice Cold Ice Hockey: Junior Edition
Infiltration
item.comment:
Enjoyable, but very fiddly with lots of little tokens and cards and such. For a fairly short game, set-up can take a bit. Doesn't seem to be a whole lot of variation from play to play right now, the thief who tags behind the others and cleans up the first floor seems to have the best chance to escape and win, rushing and raiding the second floor just doesn't seem worth it.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i]

item.name: Istanbul
item.comment:
Worker placement with a twist. I like it, but I like the twist on the genre that another worker placement game from this year took a bit more. Presents much more of a puzzle than other worker placement games. The twist makes you rather more reliant on other player's moves, thus making it difficult to plan ahead. Can make what should be a rather quick worker placement game turn into overly long games with AP-prone players. The modular board (well, tiles) adds replayability, always a plus. I personally would not have given it the 2014 Kennerspiel des Jahres over Rococo.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i] [b]#9[/b] [i]in Matt's Favorite Board Games of 2014[/i]

item.name: Kemet
item.wishlistcomment: Updated 11/13/13 - Katie absolutely loves games with auctions and I love games with area control and conflict, so this game might just appeal quite a bit to both of us. Also heavily considering Kemet, but I think the Greek mythos appeals more to Katie than Egyptian.

item.name: King of New York
item.comment:
A bit more complex version of King of Tokyo that relies slightly more on mechanisms besides the dice. I still have to be in a dice-chunking mood to enjoy it, but it's pretty good for a dice-chunker.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i] [b]#13[/b] [i]in Matt's Favorite Board Games of 2014[/i]

item.name: Kingdom Builder
item.comment:
Love it! Thought this was an economic game at first glance, but it's really an area control game. Plays very quickly, and the board/map, locations, and victory conditions are different in every game, meaning you never play the same setting twice. I love the variety that provides, and though someone else in our group already has it, I'm definitely considering it for our own collection.
[i]4/5[/i]

item.name: Last Night on Earth: The Zombie Game
item.wishlistcomment: A favorite that someone else in our board game group has, would love to add it to our own collection. Though I think, to be different, I want Invasion from Outer Space first. Be fun for solo play too.

item.name: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
Lords of Waterdeep: Scoundrels of Skullport
Marvel Dice Masters: Avengers vs. X-Men
item.comment:
One of my favorite two-player games in a while, but WizKids and the competitive scene are a mess, and I don't enjoy chasing rares/super rares. I would have much preferred this (and still be playing it) with model closer to that of Fantasy Flight's LCGs.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i] [b]#7[/b] [i]in Matt's Favorite Board Games of 2014[/i]

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment:
A very simple wargame, easy to teach and easy to pick up. One of my wife's favorites, likely one of few pure combat games that she'll ever enjoy. It's quite reliant on dice, but there's enough tactical decisions to prevent you from feeling like you lose on poor luck alone.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]5/5[/i] [b]#5[/b] [i]in Matt's Top Ten[/i] [b]#7[/b] [i]in Katie's Top Ten[/i]

item.name: Merchants & Marauders
item.comment:
A board game version of Sid Meier's Pirates! Captivating theme and interesting mechanics, but can be very long and unforgiving with player captain deaths in the game.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]4/5[/i]

item.name: Monopoly Deal Card Game
item.comment:
A fun, simple, and short set-matching game with a whole lot of "take-that" card play. Much more enjoyable than the Monopoly board game ever was!
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i]

item.name: Monopoly: Here and Now – The World Edition
item.comment:
Not as bad as board game aficionados say, not as great as casual Americans think. I somewhat enjoy Monopoly, but it pales in comparison with all the other great board games out there. I like the credit cards, always prefer cards/chips and such over paper money, but that aside, I prefer the classic variant over the here and now world version.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]2/5[/i]

item.name: Mr. Jack
item.comment:
A great two-player game that plays quickly and is easy to teach.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i]

item.name: Munchkin Deluxe
item.comment:
This is one of the first take-that card games we got into (aside from obviously growing up with games like Uno), and it's an enjoyable game every now and then. However, as we've played more and more games, this continually fails to impress and makes it to the table rarely now. Yeah, we have fun with it, but there's so many other games that are more enjoyable...
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]2/5[/i]

item.name: Orléans
item.comment:
I'm as shocked as anyone that this one's here. Most folks know of my intense dislike of dice and/or randomness for the sake of randomness. So a worker placement game with different types of workers (ala Manhattan Project) that revolves entirely around drawing workers randomly from a bag didn't seem quite up my alley. I was very wrong. There's a lot of engine building and such early on that isn't affected by the random worker draws. Once you're set-up, the randomness adds a very tactical element where you must make decisions on the fly based on what you draw. It's brilliant, I love it.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]4/5[/i] [b]#1[/b] [i]in Matt's Favorite Board Games of 2014[/i]

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment:
One of a couple games that Katie and I have wildly varied opinions on. This was one of our first cooperative games and I enjoyed it quite a bit at first. As time has gone on though, I now find it rather dull. It seems, from the games we have played, that there must be an extensive amount of discussion and debate on who should do what in order to be successful in this game, and that causes the game to drag on much longer than it ought to. I have found that I would rather rush through this game and lose than draw it out for a long while and win. I'm also not a big fan of the board and components. Ironically, I quite enjoyed the variants introduced with Pandemic's expansion pack, but Katie and others have not. In the end, when it comes to fighting cooperatively against wooden cubes, I much prefer Flash Point over Pandemic.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i] [b]#5[/b] [i]in Katie's Top Ten[/i]

item.name: Pandemic: Contagion
item.comment:
But Matt, you hate Pandemic! But guys, you play as the virus and kill cities! I guess, more importantly, it's not co-op.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i] [b]#14[/b] [i]in Matt's Favorite Board Games of 2014[/i]

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Base Set
Power Grid
item.comment:
After just a few plays, this is quickly becoming a favorite of both of ours. We played a couple of times on board game night and it went very well, so we added it to our own collection along with the Robots. It's been a great addition, as it is quite easy to leave out and stop a game after a few turns, then pick it up and resume later on.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]5/5[/i] [b]#2[/b] [i]in Matt's Top Ten[/i] [b]#9[/b] [i]in Katie's Top Ten[/i]

item.name: Quarriors!
item.wishlistcomment: Still considering picking up for ourselves. Played once, and I prefer Dominion judging by that playthrough alone.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.wishlistcomment: A favorite that someone else in our board game group has, and I would love to add it to our own collection, along with the expansions. Unfortunately, I don't think Katie will ever pick up the iconography in this game.

item.name: Risk Legacy
item.wishlistcomment: Updated 11/13/13 - Eventually, I'd like a copy of this game.. Katie and I plan on starting a fresh board and new campaign with two of our best friends, who are Risk fiends. Unfortunately, they live in Georgia and we won't even see them until next summer, so this is sitting on the back-burner for now.

item.name: RoboRally
item.comment:
I think I'll really love this game in the right environment with the right people, and the right amount of people. But an 8-player game with people who weren't paying attention wasn't just chaotic, it was stressful, irritating, and a pretty awful experience altogether.
[i]3/5[/i]
item.wishlistcomment: I think I like this game, but we had an awful experience with a crowded 8-player game on a single board. Would like to play more before acquiring for my collection.

item.name: Roll for the Galaxy
item.comment:
Did somebody say dice? I love the theme and the iconography is a bit easier to pick up than Race for the Galaxy, but each time I play this I am left with the overwhelming feeling that I'd rather just play Race instead.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i] [b]#12[/b] [i]in Matt's Favorite Board Games of 2014[/i]

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
Scoville
item.comment:
Very unique game. The mixing mechanic will remind people of Fresco, but the gameplay is starkly different. Pepper placement is very important, and the method of pick-up brings in all sorts of interesting route-taking and path-blocking strategies. Bidding for turn-order, and turn-order varying by phase (ala Power Grid) is also entertaining.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]4/5[/i] [b]#5[/b] [i]in Matt's Favorite Board Games of 2014[/i]

item.name: Sheriff of Nottingham
item.comment:
I was surprised with how much I enjoyed this... There's honestly not much of a game here as far as mechanisms go, it is all about the players involved and properly reading them, calling their bluffs, and a bit of pattern analysis. And all of that is actually stuff I enjoy, so there you go.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i] [b]#11[/b] [i]in Matt's Favorite Board Games of 2014[/i]

item.name: Small World
item.comment:
One of our first board game purchases, coming closely on the heels of fellow Days of Wonder products Ticket to Ride and Memoir '44. This hits a sweet spot for both of us, as a competitive strategy game with minimal luck, and sits at #6 on both of our current top ten lists.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]4/5[/i] [b]#6[/b] [i]in Matt's Top Ten[/i] [b]#6[/b] [i]in Katie's Top Ten[/i]

item.name: Small World Underground
item.wishlistcomment: Small World sits at #6 in my top ten as well as Katie's top ten, and remains one of our most often played games with our board game group and family members. We've grabbed all of the expansions that we're interested in, now it's time to pick up Underground, likely followed by Realms at some point in the future.

item.name: Small World: Grand Dames of Small World
Splendor
item.comment:
It's interesting, but individual groups seem to go through the same few patterns with this. Everyone starts out with a basic engine-building strategy. Eventually, players figure out they can get an edge on the engine-builders if they go for a high-tier strategy. Other players figure out they can easily derail the high-tier strategists by hoarding the gems they need. And you end up with a well-balanced game with multiple winning approaches... at which point, the game is mostly determined by the random order that the cards turn up in. Well, that's disappointing. This started as an easy favorite, but unfortunately it just bores me at this point.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i] [b]#15[/b] [i]in Matt's Favorite Board Games of 2014[/i]

item.name: Star Realms
item.comment:
I vastly prefer the Dominion-style deck-builders (all your options for purchase available from the beginning) over the Ascension-style deck-builders (narrow selection of randomly drawn cards available), but this game pretty much perfects the Ascension style. The best benefit of this style is probably the painless and quick set-up. Sure, I prefer Dominion and its ilk, but is it worth the extra 15 minutes of set-up? In that same timeframe, you could have set up and played a whole game of Star Realms.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i] [b]#10[/b] [i]in Matt's Favorite Board Games of 2014[/i]

item.name: Star Wars: The Card Game – A Dark Time
Star Wars: The Card Game – Assault on Echo Base
Star Wars: The Card Game – Edge of Darkness
Star Wars: The Card Game – Escape from Hoth
Star Wars: The Card Game – The Battle of Hoth
Star Wars: The Card Game – The Desolation of Hoth
Star Wars: The Card Game – The Search for Skywalker
Suburbia
item.wishlistcomment: I have really enjoyed all of the preview that I have seen for this game, I would love to pick it up.

item.name: Thurn and Taxis
item.wishlistcomment: Katie is a big route-building fan, and this looks like one of the best.

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment:
This is Katie's favorite game of all-time. I much prefer heavier route/network-building games that involve resources and/or stocks, such as Airlines Europe or Power Grid. Still, this was our gateway game, and the first game that really got us into board games, so even for me it will always hold a special spot on our shelves.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i] [b]#1[/b] [i]in Katie's Top Ten[/i]

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 1 – Team Asia & Legendary Asia
item.wishlistcomment: Ticket to Ride is Katie's favorite game, but we only have the India/Switzerland expansion board thus far. It'd be nice to add some variety in our Ticket to Ride games, and the team variant would be great for our weekly board game group.

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 2 – India & Switzerland
Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 3 – The Heart of Africa
Tiny Epic Kingdoms
item.comment:
Captures the feel of a 4X civilization building game in a tiny package and a 30-minute game. Quite an accomplishment, though still a bit too simple to give the same thrill that comes with the epic 4X games.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i] [b]#6[/b] [i]in Matt's Favorite Board Games of 2014[/i]

item.name: Tsuro
item.comment:
One of our favorite fillers, plays very quick and with up to 8 players, even though there's not a whole lot of substance to it.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i]

item.name: Tsuro of the Seas
item.wishlistcomment: Tsuro is one of our favorite light fillers and Katie's been interested in picking this up since it came out.

item.name: UNO
item.comment:
Classic fun take-that card game. Still a much, much better game than Fluxx.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i]

item.name: The War to Prevent Southern Secession
Warhammer 40,000: Conquest
item.comment:
My third favorite LCG ended up in the bargain bin when they announced a reprint of my second favorite LCG. Oops. Unfortunately, I only have the brainpower for maintaining interesting decks in an LCG or two at a time... though my wallet considers this a fortuitous thing.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]4/5[/i] [b]#4[/b] [i]in Matt's Favorite Board Games of 2014[/i]

item.name: The Werewolves of Miller's Hollow
item.comment:
Ugh, player elimination. Reminded me of how much (and why) I love The Resistance. Also, the Fortune Teller was a doofus who had no clue what he was doing and advocated the lynching of three townspeople, despite knowing at one point who ALL THREE of the Werewolves were. Of course, I know this because I was eliminated in the first round and got to sit back and watch everything. /sigh
1/5

item.name: Wits & Wagers Family
item.comment:
Wits & Wagers is a great light party game for non-gamer friends and gamers alike. We like the chips from the party version and the questions from the family version. We'll probably add the variable wager odds mat from the original version eventually.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i]

item.name: Wits & Wagers Party
item.comment:
Wits & Wagers is a great light party game for non-gamer friends and gamers alike. We like the chips from the party version and the questions from the family version. We'll probably add the variable wager odds mat from the original version eventually.
[b]Rating:[/b] [i]3/5[/i]
